sos.title: SOS Distress Message Generator
sos.description: Use this guide to correctly formulate a distress call on VHF channel 16. Fill in the placeholders with your specific information.

alert.title: For Real Emergencies Only
alert.description: Transmitting a false distress signal is illegal and dangerous. Use only in situations of grave and imminent danger.

step1.title: MAYDAY, MAYDAY, MAYDAY
step1.description: The international signal for grave and imminent danger. Repeat it three times to ensure it's heard and distinguished from less urgent calls.

step2.title: This is...
step2.description: State the name of your vessel three times and your call sign or other identification once. Repeating the name helps in noisy conditions.

step3.title: MAYDAY
step3.description: Repeat the distress signal once more, followed by your vessel's name.

step4.title: Position
step4.description: Give your position as accurately as possible. Use latitude/longitude, a landmark, or bearing and distance from a known point.

step5.title: Nature of Distress
step5.description: Clearly and concisely state what is wrong. E.g., 'on fire', 'sinking', 'medical emergency'.

step6.title: Assistance Required
step6.description: State the type of help you need. E.g., 'require immediate assistance'.

step7.title: Persons on Board (POB)
step7.description: State the number of people on board. This is critical information for rescue teams.

step8.title: Other Information
step8.description: Provide any other details that could help rescuers, such as 'abandoning to liferaft', 'vessel is a blue sailboat', '4-meter waves'.

step9.title: Over
step9.description: Indicates the end of your transmission, inviting a response.

step10.title: Wait
step10.description: Release the transmit button and listen. Wait for at least 15-20 seconds for a response before repeating the call, starting from the second MAYDAY.

clouds.title: Cloud Types
clouds.description: Basic identification of clouds by altitude and appearance.

cirrus.name: Cirrus (Ci)
cirrus.description: Detached clouds in the form of white, delicate filaments or white or mostly white patches or narrow bands. They have a fibrous (hair-like) appearance, or a silky sheen, or both.

cirrocumulus.name: Cirrocumulus (Cc)
cirrocumulus.description: Thin, white patch, sheet, or layer of cloud without shading, composed of very small elements in the form of grains, ripples, etc., merged or separate, and more or less regularly arranged; most of the elements have an apparent width of less than one degree.

cirrostratus.name: Cirrostratus (Cs)
cirrostratus.description: Transparent, whitish cloud veil of fibrous (hair-like) or smooth appearance, totally or partly covering the sky, and generally producing halo phenomena.

altocumulus.name: Altocumulus (Ac)
altocumulus.description: White or grayish, or both white and grayish, patch, sheet or layer of cloud, generally with shading, composed of laminae, rounded masses, rolls, etc., which are sometimes partly fibrous or diffuse and which may or may not be merged.

altostratus.name: Altostratus (As)
altostratus.description: Grayish or bluish cloud sheet or layer of striated, fibrous or uniform appearance, totally or partly covering the sky, and having parts thin enough to reveal the sun at least vaguely, as through ground glass. Does not show halo phenomena.

nimbostratus.name: Nimbostratus (Ns)
nimbostratus.description: Gray cloud layer, often dark, the appearance of which is rendered diffuse by more or less continuously falling rain or snow, which in most cases reaches the ground. It is thick enough throughout to blot out the sun.

stratus.name: Stratus (St)
stratus.description: Generally gray cloud layer with a fairly uniform base, which may give drizzle, ice prisms, or snow grains. When the sun is visible through the cloud, its outline is clearly discernible.

stratocumulus.name: Stratocumulus (Sc)
stratocumulus.description: Gray or whitish, or both gray and whitish, patch, sheet or layer of cloud which almost always has dark parts, composed of tessellations, rounded masses, rolls, etc., which are non-fibrous and which may or may not be merged.

cumulus.name: Cumulus (Cu)
cumulus.description: Detached clouds, generally dense and with sharp outlines, developing vertically in the form of rising mounds, domes or towers, of which the bulging upper part often resembles a cauliflower. The sunlit parts of these clouds are mostly brilliant white; their base is relatively dark and nearly horizontal.

cumulonimbus.name: Cumulonimbus (Cb)
cumulonimbus.description: Heavy and dense cloud, with a considerable vertical extent, in the form of a mountain or huge towers. At least part of its upper portion is usually smooth, fibrous or striated, and nearly always flattened; this part often spreads out in the shape of an anvil or vast plume.

purposes.port_a: Indicates the port side of a channel when returning from sea (Region A).

purposes.port_b: Indicates the port side of a channel when returning from sea (Region B).
purposes.starboard_b: Indicates the starboard side of a channel when returning from sea (Region B).
purposes.north: Indicates that safe water lies to the North.
purposes.south: Indicates that safe water lies to the South.
purposes.east: Indicates that safe water lies to the East.
purposes.west: Indicates that safe water lies to the West.
purposes.isolated_danger: Erected on a danger of limited extent which has navigable water all around it.
purposes.safe_water: Indicates that there is navigable water all around the mark, such as a mid-channel or landfall buoy.
purposes.special_mark: Indicates a special area or feature whose nature may be found by consulting charts or sailing directions.

mnemonics.port_a: On returning, green to starboard (green with green), red to port (red with red).
mnemonics.starboard_a: On returning, green to starboard (green with green), red to port (red with red).
mnemonics.port_b: Red Right Returning. The red buoy is on your starboard side when returning from sea.
mnemonics.starboard_b: Red Right Returning. The red buoy is on your starboard side when returning from sea.
mnemonics.north: Two cones pointing up (North). Continuous very quick or quick white flashing light.
mnemonics.south: Two cones pointing down (South). 6 very quick flashes + 1 long flash.
mnemonics.east: Cones point away from each other (base to base). 3 very quick flashes.
mnemonics.west: Cones point towards each other (vertex to vertex). 9 very quick flashes.
mnemonics.isolated_danger: Two black spheres, two white flashes in a group.
mnemonics.safe_water: Spherical mark with vertical stripes. One long white flash every 10 seconds.
mnemonics.special_mark: Yellow color, 'X' topmark. Yellow light, any rhythm not conflicting with others.

vessels.noMarks: No daylight marks are required for this situation.

R23.title: R23 - Power-driven vessel underway
R23.description: Standard lights for a power-driven vessel over 50m in length.
R23.explanation: Vessels over 50m must show two masthead lights, the aft one higher than the forward one. Vessels under 50m may, but are not required to, show the second masthead light.

R24.title: R24 - Towing and pushing
R24.description: Lights and marks for vessels engaged in towing operations.

towing_gt200.title: Towing, tow > 200m
towing_gt200.description: A power-driven vessel when towing, and the length of the tow exceeds 200 meters.
towing_gt200.explanation: Three masthead lights in a vertical line indicate a long tow. A towing light (yellow) is shown at the stern above the sternlight.

towing_lt200.title: Towing, tow < 200m
towing_lt200.description: A power-driven vessel when towing, and the length of the tow is less than 200 meters.
towing_lt200.explanation: Two masthead lights in a vertical line indicate a standard towing operation. A towing light (yellow) is shown at the stern.

pushing.title: Pushing ahead
pushing.description: A power-driven vessel when pushing another vessel ahead in a composite unit.
pushing.explanation: When rigidly connected in a composite unit, they are regarded as a single power-driven vessel and exhibit the lights for Rule 23.

R25.title: R25 - Sailing vessel underway
R25.description: Lights for a sailing vessel underway. May also show optional tricolor or all-round lights.
R25.explanation: Standard configuration is sidelights and a sternlight. A tricolor light at the masthead is a common option for sailboats under 20m. When motoring, even with sails up, it must display the lights of a power-driven vessel and a cone shape, apex downwards, during the day.

R26.title: R26 - Fishing vessels
R26.description: Lights and marks for vessels engaged in fishing.

trawling.title: Trawling
trawling.description: Engaged in trawling (dragging a net through the water).
trawling.explanation: Green over white all-round lights. 'Green over white, trawling at night'. When making way, also shows sidelights and sternlight.

fishing_not_trawling.title: Fishing (not trawling)
fishing_not_trawling.description: Engaged in fishing other than trawling, with gear extending more than 150m.
fishing_not_trawling.explanation: Red over white all-round lights. 'Red over white, fishing at night'. When making way, also shows sidelights and sternlight.

R27.title: R27 - Vessels Not Under Command or Restricted
R27.description: Vessels that cannot maneuver as required by the rules.

nuc.title: Not Under Command (NUC)
nuc.description: Unable to maneuver due to some exceptional circumstance.
nuc.explanation: Two all-round red lights in a vertical line. 'Red over red, the Captain is dead'. If making way, also shows sidelights and sternlight. By day, two balls in a vertical line.

ram.title: Restricted in Ability to Maneuver (RAM)
ram.description: Unable to keep out of the way of another vessel due to the nature of her work (e.g., dredging, survey, replenishment).
ram.explanation: Red-white-red all-round lights in a vertical line. By day, ball-diamond-ball in a vertical line. If making way, also shows normal power-driven vessel lights.

R28.title: R28 - Vessel constrained by her draft
R28.description: A power-driven vessel which because of her draft is severely restricted in her ability to deviate from her course.
R28.explanation: In addition to normal power-driven vessel lights, a vessel constrained by her draft may exhibit three all-round red lights in a vertical line. By day, a cylinder.

R29.title: R29 - Pilot vessel
R29.explanation: When on duty, shows white over red all-round lights. 'White over red, pilot ahead'. When underway, also shows normal sidelights and sternlight. When at anchor, shows anchor lights in addition to the pilot lights.

R30.title: R30 - Anchored vessels and vessels aground
R30.description: Lights and marks for vessels at anchor or aground.

anchored.title: At Anchor
anchored.description: A vessel at anchor. Vessels over 50m show two all-round white lights; vessels under 50m show one.
anchored.explanation: An all-round white light where it can best be seen. If over 50m, a second, lower all-round white light at or near the stern. By day, a single ball.

aground.title: Aground
aground.explanation: In addition to anchor lights, a vessel aground shows two all-round red lights in a vertical line. By day, three balls in a vertical line.
